Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: I glanced at my phone as it buzzed on the dashboard, the snow swirling outside making the city look almost unrecognizable. My acquaintance, Mark, had texted: “Hey, can you help me move some boxes today? I’m really stuck.” I knew he didn’t have many people to ask, and I’d always tried to be there for him when I could. But right now, I had a passenger in the backseat, nervously checking her watch every few minutes. She had an international flight to catch, and the roads were a mess—slick with ice, traffic crawling. As a taxi driver, I was expected to get her to the airport safely and on time, no matter the weather. But Mark’s message tugged at me. He was counting on me, and I didn’t want to let him down. My hands tightened on the steering wheel, my mind racing between the responsibility I felt toward my passenger and the loyalty I owed to Mark. The snow kept falling, and I felt trapped between two worlds, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
